bioghist.p: Daniel Garrison Brinton (1837-1899) was an American archaeologist and ethnologist. During the Civil War, he was a surgeon in the Union army. After the war, Brinton practiced medicine in West Chester, Pennsylvania for several years before joining the Academy of Natural Sciences in Philadelphia as a professor of ethnology and archaeology in 1884. In 1886 he became professor of American linguistics and archaeology in the University of Pennsylvania. From 1874 to 1887 he was editor of the weekly Medical and Surgical Reporter.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Daniel Garrison Brinton. Most of the materials relate to his professional life, but there is also a small amount of family correspondence in the collection. Brinton's professional papers include correspondence; lecture notes on American Indian origins, languages, ethnology, and on American and Central American archeology; scrapbooks of Briton's "Current Notes on Anthropology" column; a scrapbook of newspaper clippings and several photographs on American Indians, in Spanish and English; reprints of articles by Brinton and others; hand-drawn and printed maps, many of Mexico and South America; and several volumes containing Brinton's notes and extracts from texts on Central and North American Indian ethnology and language, comparative religion, and American history. These volumes include two notebooks focusing on the Tzental (Tzeltal) Indians in Mexico. The collection also includes several memorials and obituaries of Brinton.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
